This looks _suspiciously_ like my [Modular Utility Building](https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6838588), don't you think? 
OK, yeah, I fancied having one that was full height - that is, the same height as a GW Sector Fronteris hab block, and therefore also the same height as a [Fronteris style bunker](https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:6988922). It is, very approximately, 60x60x70mm.
For my own use I thought I'd go all in on the vents; make it some sort of cooling tower type thing, with a simple style vaguely influenced by some belfry louvres. I've kept in some more basic walls too, if that's more your style (or you plan to embellish them yourself).

### Compatibility

Style-wise, it obviously takes heavy cues from the Sector Fronteris hab units.

The pipe ports are the standard size expected on GW's 40k terrain - 25.6mm diameter.

The side pipe ports have a centre-line height of 14.5mm, which matches other terrain, e.g. Thermic Plasma Conduits.. Their outer face is 30.5mm from the centre point, so if you have two opposite each other they'll be 61mm apart, which should be a familiar size to those used to e.g. Sector Mechanicus components.

The roof is the same height as that of a Sector Fronteris hab unit, and the roof with a port should match the ports on those hab units too.

### Assembly

You will need:
* 4x *pillars*
* 4x *walls*
* 1x *roof*
If you chose walls with *ports*, you'll also need
* 1+ *pipe ends*

Walls push into pillars from behind. I recommend putting the roof in unglued as you put together the rest, then gluing it in last.

Pillars can be mirrored for a bit more variety.

### Pre-supports

The supported files here are the way I did them for myself, successfully. Is it the best? No. The walls and pillars are definitely over-supported, but I wasn't going to go back and change something that worked.

As you may see from the pictures, I did _not_ print non-louvred walls. The supports have been applied in the same way, but I have not actually printed these specifically.

### FAQ

* What's with the extra holes on the pipe ports in the photos but not on the STLs?
 _I have bizarre hopes of putting a lot of magnets everywhere. I'm not doing this in a way that I think makes sense to most people, so I didn't think it was worth sharing those. You can have the clean ones that actually look good by themselves!_

Justification du tag SUP :

~~~
The supported files here are the way I did them for myself, successfully. Is it the best? No. The walls and pillars are definitely over-supported, but I wasn't going to go back and change something that worked.
~~~

I've added extra detail and scaled this specifically for 6mm scale FDM printing. I changed the building to add a side garage, rather than a glasshouse.

This set is intended to be compatible with the other 6mm SciFi terrain sets I have adapted and released. Please search my other things for more.

**Go to the "Thing Files" tab to individually download the files - Thingiverse is giving an odd 404 error when trying to use the "Download all files" buttons**

The perfect restaurant for watching S7 broadcasts or kicking back with the local mercs for a beer. This building is designed to be 3D printed as terrain for 6mm tabletop gaming. The top of the building is large and flat enough to support placing units on top in all hexes for playability. The top of version B has additional supports for two edge hexes for extra stability. It is 1 level tall in most areas, except for the front two hexes where it is 1.5 levels tall, if you're playing a specific mecha tabletop game.

There are eight files. For each of version A and B, one has the building on hexes, another is hexless so that you can print the one that fits your playstyle, and there are two more versions that have the text removed from the front of the building. Using the NoText versions, you can paint custom names on the front, print off logos to attach, or leave it blank.

As always, tipping is appreciated at: paypal.me/rainingfire416

Notable features:
-An in-universe themed restaurant name.
-Fantastic custom logo and details to give it a proper BBQ joint look.
-Detailed design including doors, windows, and a detailed roof with greebles.

The model units are in mm and it is scaled such that the hexes are 33mm from flat-to-flat, which is perfect for modern hex maps using 33mm hexes. You can always resize it if your hexes are slightly smaller/larger.

Please post pictures and leave feedback if you make this yourself! I'd love to see prints and use the feedback to adjust overhangs, detail levels, etc. on this model and future ones as well.

Working of a new idea.... using foam core or coroplast to make the roof/floors of the buildings.
So the floor is designed to slot together to prevent wobble.
Stair/scaffolding has peg holes for 1.75mm filament to serve to lock parts together, and all sections are designed to seam together for forming bigger buildings.

This is a remix, I can't find the original source, but I fixed them, and modified the lenghts so that they can actually fit together, and added column to make corners stronger.

These are thin so you can easily cut them once printed to make them as ruins. You can also use them, once cutted up, to add on Titan's bases.

I printed them in PLA, I haven't tried them in resin but I think they would be too fragile.

In the 31st century, this originally Canadian business has rebranded to be even more popular! This building is designed to be 3D printed as terrain for 6mm tabletop gaming. The top of the building is large and flat enough to support placing units on top for playability. It is 2 levels tall on the higher levels and 1 level tall on the lower levels if you're playing a specific mecha tabletop game.

This is a two part print. Part 1 of the building can be used standalone as any large commercial building if you print the version without text and a logo. Part 2 is an automotive center add-on that can be placed on either side of the main building to make it larger, as seen in the photos above.

There are six files. Two have the building sections on hexes, two are hexless so that you can print the ones that fits your playstyle, and there are two more versions of Part 1 that have the text removed from the front of the building. Using the NoText versions, you can populate your tabletop with custom commercial/big-box stores by painting names on the front or printing off logos to attach.

As always, tipping is appreciated at: paypal.me/rainingfire416

Notable features:
-Based off of a very popular Canadian business, using a similar font and building design style.
-Detailed design including large front windows, two main entrances, garage doors, windows, and bollards to protect the building from bad drivers.

The model units are in mm and it is scaled such that the hexes are 33mm from flat-to-flat, which is perfect for modern hex maps using 33mm hexes. You can always resize it if your hexes are slightly smaller/larger.

Please post pictures and leave feedback if you make this yourself! I'd love to see prints and use the feedback to adjust overhangs, detail levels, etc. on this model and future ones as well.

A radome designed to be 3D printed as terrain for 6mm tabletop gaming. These provide great scatter terrain to add detail to your military bases. It also looks great in an open field as extra cover. The top of the B version is flat and can support a unit placed on top for playability. It is 2 levels tall if you're playing a specific mecha tabletop game.

There are four files. One of each building both with and without hexes so that you can print the one that fits your playstyle. Remember to print the B version if you want the extra support pegs to support units on top for playability. I advise printing these in resin if possible because they are small enough that they don't take much resin, and the details show up smoother.

As always, tipping is appreciated at: paypal.me/rainingfire416

Notable features:
-This building goes perfectly with the other military buildings I've designed.

In the distant future, humanity has learnt that hexagonal buildings are superior!

They're hexagonal residential buildings, for 6mm / 1:285 gaming - primarily Battletech but also Epic 40k and other games at that scale.

The buildings are combinations of hexagonal towers that equate to level 1, 2 and 3 within Battletech. I've set level 1 at about 25mm which allows small mechs to still see over them and level 2 at about 55mm which blocks visibility of even the largest mechs I've tested. Each level after that goes up 30mm.

They're designed to fit within the "standard" Battletech map hexes of 33mm flat edge to flat edge as is used in the current boxed sets. They also have a roof designed to allow Mech models to be placed on them.

The models are designed to be mostly supportless on an FDM printer and have printed fine on my Ender 3.

The two models shown are earlier test prints and the final models as uploaded include a couple of more details. I'll be replacing the images once I paint up one of the updated versions.

A library building designed to be 3D printed as terrain for 6mm tabletop gaming. The top of the building is large and flat enough to support a unit placed on top for all 23 hex locations. It is 6 levels tall if you're playing a specific mecha tabletop game.

There are two files. One has the building on hexes and the other is hexless so that you can print the one that fits your playstyle. Further, there is a second variation of this building, uploaded as “Library 1A” here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:4598463

The difference between the two buildings is that 1A is the "original" version, and for 1B the faces that extend from the side of the upper part of the building do not extend as far. If you do not print at a high enough resolution then the bottom part of those faces may sag slightly on 1A. This is not an issue if you print at a high resolution, and can clean up well if you do experience sagging, but you may choose to use 1B to speed up the print time by lowering the resolution, or because your printer resolution cannot go high enough to print those extra faces without issue. 1B makes the building design less prominent, but it means that if you print the building at a low resolution then those parts won't sag at the bottom.

Notable features:
-Detailed design including doors, windows, loading docks, steps to an exterior walkway around the building, and a detailed roof area with greebles such as ducting.
-Visually interesting exterior design.
-The second floor has a curved wall supporting the larger floors on the upper part of the building. This means that the building should print without any supports, and conveniently it is also how the real life building is designed.
-This building is closely based on a real life building. It is designed as a library, but you could use it as an office building or something else if you're creative.
-This building is fairly large and would provide a great addition to your urban terrain.

The model units are in mm and it is scaled such that the hexes are 33mm from flat-to-flat, which is perfect for modern hex maps using 33mm hexes. You can always resize it if your hexes are slightly smaller/larger.

Please post pictures and leave feedback if you make this yourself! I'd love to see prints and use the feedback to adjust overhangs, detail levels, etc. on this model and future ones as well.

A mixed use building designed to be 3D printed as terrain for 6mm tabletop gaming. The top of the building is large and flat enough to support a unit placed on top for all 7 hex locations. It is 2 levels tall if you're playing a specific mecha tabletop game.

There are two files. One has the building on hexes and the other is hexless so that you can print the one that fits your playstyle. Further, there is a second variation of this building, uploaded as “Mixed Use Building 2B” here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:4598435

The difference between the two buildings is that 2B has simplified windows and slightly different placement of the windows around the building. This provides you with different versions of the same building that you can use to vary the look of your terrain.

Notable features:
-Detailed design including doors, windows, and a detailed roof area with greebles such as ducting.
-This building is designed as a mixed use building, meaning that the ground floor could be commercial retail space while the upper floors are used as apartments. Of course, you can use the building as whatever you'd like, and you could even use it as a manufacturing facility, storage facility, or something else if you're creative.

The model units are in mm and it is scaled such that the hexes are 33mm from flat-to-flat, which is perfect for modern hex maps using 33mm hexes. You can always resize it if your hexes are slightly smaller/larger.

Please post pictures and leave feedback if you make this yourself! I'd love to see prints and use the feedback to adjust overhangs, detail levels, etc. on this model and future ones as well.
